subsections.title: Non-Ionizing Radiation, MPE Limits
subsections.label: subsec:non-ionizing
prompts: Explain the concept of non-ionizing radiation and how it differs from ionizing radiation. Include examples and implications for human exposure.
Describe the concept of Maximum Permissible Exposure (MPE) limits and how they vary with frequency. Provide examples of how these limits are applied in amateur radio.
Discuss the role of duty cycle in determining safe RF radiation exposure levels. Explain how changes in duty cycle affect power density and exposure limits.
Identify and explain the factors that affect RF exposure of people near an amateur station antenna. Include frequency, power level, distance, and radiation pattern.
Explain why exposure limits vary with frequency and how the human body absorbs RF energy differently at different frequencies.
Describe the acceptable methods for determining whether a station complies with FCC RF exposure regulations. Include calculations, computer modeling, and field strength measurements.
Discuss the hazards of touching an antenna during transmission, focusing on RF burns and how they occur.
Explain the actions that can be taken to reduce exposure to RF radiation, such as relocating antennas or transmitters.
Describe how to ensure a station stays in compliance with RF safety regulations, including re-evaluating the station after changes to the transmitter or antenna system.
Explain the definition of duty cycle during the averaging time for RF exposure and its importance in determining safe exposure levels.
Compare and contrast RF radiation with ionizing radiation, focusing on their effects on human cells and DNA.
Discuss the responsibilities of the station licensee in ensuring that no person is exposed to RF energy above the FCC exposure limits.
